1.comment: ASSERT → -mi The evidential suffix confirms the speaker's direct knowledge/certainty .EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → tiyan The verb meaning "to exist/be present" (used for tangible objects).existing → tiyan Explicitly stated (vs. implied in verbless constructions).fish → challwa Unmarked noun as subject.

2.comment: The single word contains: Spatial interrogative (may-) Locative marker (-pi) Question particle (-taq) .existing → Implied through context .

3.cq: There is a fish next to the coral head.
3.comment: ASSERT → -mi .EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → tiyan .LOCATIVE PREDICATE → qaylla-n-pi qaylla = "side" -n = possessive (its) -pi = locative (at) .existing → tiyan Explicit existential verb.   Ecological Adaptation :Rumi hatun replaces "coral head" (Andean context)."Coral head" has no native Quechua equivalent, as coral reefs are absent in the Andean highlands. While in modern Quechua writing system, we use the Spanish loanword qural (from coral), this translation strictly avoids foreign borrowings to maintain purity in the Cusco dialect.  Instead, we use:  Large/prominent rock (ᖀᖁᖆ ᖆᖂᖔᖇ) = "large/prominent rock"  Rumi = rock/stone (universal in Andean landscapes)  Large = big/great (implies importance, like a coral head’s ecological role).

4.cq: Now the fish is inside the coral head!
4.comment: 1. ASSERT → -mi . 2.LOCATIVE PREDICATE → ukhu-n-pi  ukhu = "belly/interior" (body-part metaphor) -n = possessive (its) -pi = locative (in) 3.EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → Implied by -mi . 4.existing → Inherent in -mi assertion No separate verb needed.

5.comment: Double Negation Emphasis: The standalone Manam! followed by full Mana...-chu creates layered negation for rhetorical force.  Evidential Suffix: -m in manam indicates the speaker's direct observation/certainty.

6.cq: There is no fish next to the coral head.
6.comment: 1. DENY → Mana...-chu. 2.EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → Implied by negation 3.LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -pi in qayllanpi 4.next to → qaylla-n-pi. 5.existing → Implied by challwa's absence.

7.comment: No verb needed: The exclamation stands alone as a complete emotional utterance. -má adds emotional weight to the truth claim, making it appreciative.

8.cq: It is behind the coral head now.
8.comment: ASSERT  → -mi (evidential suffix) in Qhipanmanmi. EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → Implied by verb "ayqirun".LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -man (directional) + qhipa (back/behind). CORAL HEAD → Adapted as rumi (rock). No direct translation for "coral": Quechua replaces it with culturally relevant objects (rumi). Alternative for "coral head" (if needed): Qucha rumi ("ocean rock") – if context is coastal. Rumi llaqta ("rock cluster") – to imply complexity.

9.comment: Mana = negation base -ñam = "already/anymore" (temporal negation) -chu = terminal negation marker 2.PROCESSIVE PREDICATE → rikuy Nominalized verb "rikuy" ("seeing") functions as action noun 3.PP1SG (1st Person Singular) → -ni in atinichu Ati-ni-chu = "able-I-NEG" 4. being able to → ati- Root verb "to be able" 5. seeing → rikuy Nominalized form of rikuy ("to see"). 6.Ref_1_object → Implied (fish/object from context). 7.anymore → -ñam Temporal suffix indicating cessation.

10.cq: Is it under this rock now?
10.comment: EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → Implied by context. LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -pi (in/at) + ukhu (belly).UNDER → ukhu-n-pi.

11.cq: No, It is not under this rock!
11.comment: LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -pi in rumi-pi-chu ("rock-in-not").existing → Implied through negation (non-existence in this location). Locative Scope: The -pi covers both "in" and "under" (context clarifies).

12.comment: ASSERT → -m (in rumillam) The evidential suffix confirms speaker's certainty about the attribution. 1.Affective Diminutive -lla + -m creates a double emphasis: -lla = "just/merely" (diminishing importance) -m = "indeed" (countering expectations) 2.Adjective-Noun Bond Llullu rumi behaves as a single conceptual unit ("tiny-rock")

13.comment: 1.Reduplication Hatun hatun conveys: Great size (physical) Importance (metaphorical). 2.Contrastive Focus -taq implies: "As for the fish (unlike the rock I just mentioned)..." 3.Evidential Force -mi makes this a firsthand observation (likely visual confirmation). 4.ASSERT → -mi The evidential suffix confirms the speaker's certainty about the fish's size.

14.comment: 1.ASSERT → -mi The evidential suffix confirms the speaker's direct observation (visual confirmation). 2.EXISTENTIAL PREDICATE → tiyan The verb "to exist/be present" (used for tangible beings). 3.bird → pisqu Unmarked noun (no diminutive/affective suffixes). 4.existing → tiyan Explicit existential verb (unlike implied existence in verbless constructions).

15.cq: I think it is looking at the fish
15.comment: 1. EXPRESS BELIEF (EPISTEMIC) → -chá The dubitative suffix marks the speaker’s uncertain inference. 2.PROCESSIVE PREDICATE → qhaway-ka- Qhaway = "to watch/look" -ka- = progressive/durative action. 3.PP1SG (1st Person Singular) → Implied by -chá The dubitative suffix inherently reflects the speaker’s perspective. 4.thinking → Encoded in -chá Quechua expresses belief through evidential markers, not mental verbs. 5.looking → qhaway Root verb for visual attention. 6.Ref_1_object → pisqu The bird is the subject/topic of observation.

16.comment: 1.ASK (Question) → -taq (interrogative enclitic) .2-LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -pi (locative suffix inside maypi) .3-spatial position wildcard → may- (interrogative root for "where"). 4-existing → Implied through the locative question.

17.cq: The bird is on the tree there
17.comment: 1-LOCATIVE PREDICATE → -pi (in pata-n-pi) .2-bird → pisqu-qa Pisqu = bird -qa = topic marker  3.on top of → Implied by pata 4-existing → Implied by -m

18.comment: ASSERT → Implicit in -ni (The 1st-person marker -ni inherently asserts the speaker’s direct experience) 2-PROCESSIVE PREDICATE → Riku- (The verb root rikuy ("to see") implies an active visual process) 3-PP1SG (1st Person Singular) → -ni The suffix explicitly marks the speaker as the subject ("I"). 4-Ref_1_object → Implied by context

19.cq: There is another bird above the coral head.
19.comment: existing → Implied by verb The progressive -kacha- indicates the bird is currently present/alive.
